A **kobold shaman**, k, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It has the highest [monster difficulty](/wiki/Monster_difficulty "Monster difficulty") among [kobolds](/wiki/Kobold_\(monster_class\) "Kobold (monster class)"), and is likely one of the first spellcasting monsters that the [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") will encounter. Kobold shamans have [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision") and can be seen via infravision, and will seek out [magical items](/wiki/Magical_item "Magical item") to pick up.

A kobold shaman will cast one mage [monster spell](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell") during each of its turns, and possesses [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance") like most kobolds.

A kobold shaman [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") is [poisonous](/wiki/Poisonous "Poisonous") to [eat](/wiki/Eat "Eat").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [5.2 GruntHack](#GruntHack)
  - [5.3 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [5.4 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [5.5 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [5.6 EvilHack](#EvilHack)

- [6 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly-generated kobold shamans are always hostile.

Kobold shamans may appear among the hostile kobolds that generate in [throne rooms](/wiki/Throne_room "Throne room"), as well as the various monsters that can be randomly generated by [looting](/wiki/Looting "Looting") a throne while [confused](/wiki/Confused "Confused") and carrying gold (provided there is no [chest](/wiki/Chest "Chest") on the level). A pair of kobold shamans occupy the room between the possible tool [shop](/wiki/Shop "Shop") and deli in the College Town variant of [Mine Town](/wiki/Mine_Town "Mine Town").

A kobold shaman has a 1⁄4 chance of [generating with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a stack of [darts](/wiki/Dart "Dart").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Strategy

Kobold shamans are very weak spellcasters, and their low [level](/wiki/Monster_level "Monster level") makes them unlikely to cast successfully: a level 3 kobold shaman has a 1⁄3 chance of successfully casting [psi bolt](/wiki/Psi_bolt "Psi bolt"), [cure self](/wiki/Cure_self "Cure self") or [haste self](/wiki/Haste_self_\(monster_spell\) "Haste self (monster spell)"). Psi bolt inflicts mild damage to all but the weakest characters, and haste self still leaves them at a meager 9 speed. Furthermore, their lack of a weapon attack means they will not use any darts they generate with. Most starting characters should have an easy time with them, especially with any form of ranged attack.

## History

The kobold shaman first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Kobold (Dungeons & Dragons)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kobold_\(Dungeons_%26_Dragons\) "wikipedia:Kobold (Dungeons & Dragons)")***

Kobolds are creatures that appear in many fantasy-themed works and media, which often borrow significantly from Germanic folklore - Germanic kobolds are a form of sprite that are generally benevolent if treated with kindness, but will respond to disrespect with anything ranging from pranks to even outright attacking and killing offenders.

*[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")* in particular - and by extension, *NetHack* and many of its variants - depicts the kobold as a race of small reptilian humanoids with long tails, distantly related to dragons; earlier editions gave kobolds more dog-like features, which lead to many depictions of kobolds in Japanese media leaning harder in that direction after the popularity of the anime franchise *Record of Lodoss War*. Fantasy kobolds are often considered weak "cannon fodder" monsters that can be cunning and strong in groups, similar to goblins.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), two kobold shamans are generated alongside [Kroo the Kobold King](/wiki/Kroo_the_Kobold_King "Kroo the Kobold King") in the "town" variant of his [special level](/wiki/Kobold_level "Kobold level") on level creation.

### GruntHack

In [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"), kobold shamans are replaced by [racial monster](/wiki/Racial_monster "Racial monster") [mages and shamans](/wiki/Mage_\(GruntHack\) "Mage (GruntHack)"), which kobolds are eligible to generate as.

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), kobold shamans and other kobolds have a mutual [grudge](/wiki/Grudge "Grudge") with [elves](/wiki/Elf_\(monster_attribute\) "Elf (monster attribute)").

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), kobold shamans may appear in the court of a [throne room](/wiki/Throne_room#dNetHack "Throne room") ruled by a [kobold lord](/wiki/Kobold_lord "Kobold lord").

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), kobold shamans and other spellcasters have [telepathy](/wiki/Telepathy "Telepathy"), and possessing telepathy will allow you to detect their position and vice versa. Eating a kobold shaman's corpse has a chance of conveying telepathy.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), kobold shamans and other spellcasters have telepathy, and possessing telepathy will allow you to detect their position and vice versa. Eating a kobold shaman's corpse is guaranteed to grant the player telepathy.

Kobold shamans cast clerical spells instead of mage spells, and they can cast the protection monster spell at their base level, making them somewhat tougher to fight.

## Encyclopedia entry

The race of kobolds are reputed to be an artificial creation  
of a master wizard (demi-god?). They are about 3' tall with  
a vaguely dog-like face. They bear a violent dislike of the  
Elven race, and will go out of their way to cause trouble  
for Elves at any time.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 456](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L456)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Kobold shaman

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
k kobold shaman
Difficulty 4
Attacks Spell-casting 0d0 mage
k kobold shaman
Difficulty 4
Attacks

Spell-casting 0d0 mage

Base level 2
Base experience 27
Speed 6
Base AC 6
Base MR 10
Alignment -4 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 450
Nutritional value 150
Size Small
Resistances Poison
Resistances conveyed None

A kobold shaman:

  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • is poisonous to eat.
  • is omnivorous.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • can pick up magical items.
  • has infravision.
  • can be seen through infravision.
Reference monst.c#line591

A kobold shaman, k, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. It has the highest monster difficulty among kobolds, and is likely one of the first spellcasting monsters that the hero will encounter. Kobold shamans have infravision and can be seen via infravision, and will seek out magical items to pick up.

A kobold shaman will cast one mage monster spell during each of its turns, and possesses poison resistance like most kobolds.

A kobold shaman corpse is poisonous to eat.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Origin
  • 5 Variants
    • 5.1 SLASH'EM
    • 5.2 GruntHack
    • 5.3 UnNetHack
    • 5.4 dNetHack
    • 5.5 xNetHack
    • 5.6 EvilHack
  • 6 Encyclopedia entry
  • 7 References

Generation

Randomly-generated kobold shamans are always hostile.

Kobold shamans may appear among the hostile kobolds that generate in throne rooms, as well as the various monsters that can be randomly generated by looting a throne while confused and carrying gold (provided there is no chest on the level). A pair of kobold shamans occupy the room between the possible tool shop and deli in the College Town variant of Mine Town.

A kobold shaman has a 1⁄4 chance of generating with a stack of darts.[1]

Strategy

Kobold shamans are very weak spellcasters, and their low level makes them unlikely to cast successfully: a level 3 kobold shaman has a 1⁄3 chance of successfully casting psi bolt, cure self or haste self. Psi bolt inflicts mild damage to all but the weakest characters, and haste self still leaves them at a meager 9 speed. Furthermore, their lack of a weapon attack means they will not use any darts they generate with. Most starting characters should have an easy time with them, especially with any form of ranged attack.

History

The kobold shaman first appears in NetHack 3.0.0.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Kobold (Dungeons & Dragons)

Kobolds are creatures that appear in many fantasy-themed works and media, which often borrow significantly from Germanic folklore - Germanic kobolds are a form of sprite that are generally benevolent if treated with kindness, but will respond to disrespect with anything ranging from pranks to even outright attacking and killing offenders.

Dungeons & Dragons in particular - and by extension, NetHack and many of its variants - depicts the kobold as a race of small reptilian humanoids with long tails, distantly related to dragons; earlier editions gave kobolds more dog-like features, which lead to many depictions of kobolds in Japanese media leaning harder in that direction after the popularity of the anime franchise Record of Lodoss War. Fantasy kobolds are often considered weak "cannon fodder" monsters that can be cunning and strong in groups, similar to goblins.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, two kobold shamans are generated alongside Kroo the Kobold King in the "town" variant of his special level on level creation.

GruntHack

In GruntHack, kobold shamans are replaced by racial monster mages and shamans, which kobolds are eligible to generate as.

UnNetHack

In UnNetHack, kobold shamans and other kobolds have a mutual grudge with elves.

dNetHack

In dNetHack, notdNetHack and notnotdNetHack, kobold shamans may appear in the court of a throne room ruled by a kobold lord.

xNetHack

In xNetHack, kobold shamans and other spellcasters have telepathy, and possessing telepathy will allow you to detect their position and vice versa. Eating a kobold shaman's corpse has a chance of conveying telepathy.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, kobold shamans and other spellcasters have telepathy, and possessing telepathy will allow you to detect their position and vice versa. Eating a kobold shaman's corpse is guaranteed to grant the player telepathy.

Kobold shamans cast clerical spells instead of mage spells, and they can cast the protection monster spell at their base level, making them somewhat tougher to fight.

Encyclopedia entry

The race of kobolds are reputed to be an artificial creation
of a master wizard (demi-god?). They are about 3' tall with
a vaguely dog-like face. They bear a violent dislike of the
Elven race, and will go out of their way to cause trouble
for Elves at any time.


References

  1. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 456

A '''kobold shaman''', {{monsym|kobold shaman}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It has the highest [[monster difficulty]] among [[Kobold (monster class)|kobolds]], and is likely one of the first spellcasting monsters that the [[hero]] will encounter. Kobold shamans have [[infravision]] and can be seen via infravision, and will seek out [[magical item]]s to pick up.

A kobold shaman will cast one mage [[monster spell]] during each of its turns, and possesses [[poison resistance]] like most kobolds. 

A kobold shaman [[corpse]] is [[poisonous]] to [[eat]].

==Generation==
Randomly-generated kobold shamans are always hostile.

Kobold shamans may appear among the hostile kobolds that generate in [[throne room]]s, as well as the various monsters that can be randomly generated by [[looting]] a throne while [[confused]] and carrying gold (provided there is no [[chest]] on the level). A pair of kobold shamans occupy the room between the possible tool [[shop]] and deli in the College Town variant of [[Mine Town]].

A kobold shaman has a {{frac|4}} chance of [[Monster starting inventory|generating with]] a stack of [[dart]]s.{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|456|nethack=3.6.7}}

==Strategy==
Kobold shamans are very weak spellcasters, and their low [[monster level|level]] makes them unlikely to cast successfully: a level 3 kobold shaman has a {{frac|3}} chance of successfully casting [[psi bolt]], [[cure self]] or [[Haste self (monster spell)|haste self]]. Psi bolt inflicts mild damage to all but the weakest characters, and haste self still leaves them at a meager 9 speed. Furthermore, their lack of a weapon attack means they will not use any darts they generate with. Most starting characters should have an easy time with them, especially with any form of ranged attack.

==History==
The kobold shaman first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]].

==Origin==
{{Wikipedia|Kobold (Dungeons & Dragons)}}
Kobolds are creatures that appear in many fantasy-themed works and media, which often borrow significantly from Germanic folklore - Germanic kobolds are a form of sprite that are generally benevolent if treated with kindness, but will respond to disrespect with anything ranging from pranks to even outright attacking and killing offenders.

''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' in particular - and by extension, ''NetHack'' and many of its variants - depicts the kobold as a race of small reptilian humanoids with long tails, distantly related to dragons; earlier editions gave kobolds more dog-like features, which lead to many depictions of kobolds in Japanese media leaning harder in that direction after the popularity of the anime franchise ''Record of Lodoss War''. Fantasy kobolds are often considered weak "cannon fodder" monsters that can be cunning and strong in groups, similar to goblins.

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], two kobold shamans are generated alongside [[Kroo the Kobold King]] in the "town" variant of his [[Kobold level|special level]] on level creation.

===GruntHack===
In [[GruntHack]], kobold shamans are replaced by [[racial monster]] [[Mage (GruntHack)|mages and shamans]], which kobolds are eligible to generate as.

===UnNetHack===
In [[UnNetHack]], kobold shamans and other kobolds have a mutual [[grudge]] with [[Elf (monster attribute)|elves]].

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], [[notdNetHack]] and [[notnotdNetHack]], kobold shamans may appear in the court of a [[Throne room#dNetHack|throne room]] ruled by a [[kobold lord]].

===xNetHack===
In [[xNetHack]], kobold shamans and other spellcasters have [[telepathy]], and possessing telepathy will allow you to detect their position and vice versa. Eating a kobold shaman's corpse has a chance of conveying telepathy.

===EvilHack===
In [[EvilHack]], kobold shamans and other spellcasters have telepathy, and possessing telepathy will allow you to detect their position and vice versa. Eating a kobold shaman's corpse is guaranteed to grant the player telepathy.

Kobold shamans cast clerical spells instead of mage spells, and they can cast the protection monster spell at their base level, making them somewhat tougher to fight.

==Encyclopedia entry==

The race of kobolds are reputed to be an artificial creation
of a master wizard (demi-god?).  They are about 3' tall with
a vaguely dog-like face.  They bear a violent dislike of the
Elven race, and will go out of their way to cause trouble
for Elves at any time.
</poem>}}
